Definition: In this task, you are given a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to classify the comment into two classes: obscene and non-obscene. A comment is obscene if it is considered offensive to the public sense of decency, for example because it too obviously relates to sex or contains language regarded as taboo in polite usage.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Damn!  Another cloudy day, and it's all Obama's doing!
Positive Examples.explanation: This is obscenity because it hints on sexual content that is offensive to the public sense of decency.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Be a victim or shoot back.
Positive Examples.explanation: This is unrelated to pornography or obscenity.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: dbsb, Trump could have condemned white supremacists and Nazis the way he did today (only say it like he meant it rather than like he was a hostage forced to read a statement) AND at the same time condemned the violence. They're not mutually exclusive. The fact he didn't for three days speaks volumes about his own personal beliefs.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment might be considered toxic or racism, but is not obscene.
This comment should be considered obscene because it contains explicit language of obscenity.

Comment: There is a larger problem here: twice in the 21st century, the American public has elected two grossly incompetent Presidents: Bush and now Trump. Bush was, basically, a decent guy who was in way over his head, was deeply ignorant, and was led astray by the people around him. Trump is also profoundly ignorant, but he is not a "decent guy;" he is a deeply disturbed and unfit individual. We can be thankful that, on many issues, he seems to be backing down or tempering his actions. But there is no guarantee that will continue. The next time Americans elect a President it could be someone who is much smarter, has a much stronger set of destructive principles and ideology, and who is, as a result, an even greater threat to the world. It's time to acknowledge that the USA is the most dangerous state in the world right now.

Does the county need to provide valet parking?

I'm quite impressed with how user-friendly the Glenwood transfer station is. I'm in and out in no time flat, the staff is always helpful and generally cheerful, which is impressive in a dump setting, and the place is kept fairly clean and free of tire-damaging debris. Also, the prices are incredibly low. 

I know it's popular to "trash" the government, but Lame County does garbage quite well. I hope this process keeps what's good and improves things that can be improved while keeping the long-term in mind.

Comment: I think you have it all wrong. The end result of Rosa Parks's courage -- and of the whole civil rights movement in general -- was not that from now on only black people could sit at the front of the bus, while the whites would be relegated to the back, but that  _anybody_  could sit anywhere they wanted to if a free seat was available. That's true "egalitarian society."  That's what MLK fought for, and that's what's morally right. Sending white people to the back of the bus -- or a concert venue -- is just as racist as it was to try to prevent Rosa Parks from sitting in the front, and white people have just as much right to REFUSE to move if ordered to do so as she did.

Comment: As I watched 9 more pre-orders roll in today, I had to think, darn, that's 9 more traction non-indicators for Steve.

Your opinion that pre-orders aren't a viable traction indicator is, frankly, nonsense. We clearly articulate preorders as "strong leads" in our offering circular. They are-- anyone who's put cash down, refundable or not, is a much stronger lead than someone who merely signs up for a test drive. Yes, we still have to build a compelling product, and continue to communicate that product to our pre-order customers. While some will certainly fall off, to me it seems likely they will more than be made up for from folks who are unwilling to place a preorder on something that is not yet in production, which is a very common refrain we hear.

Anyway, thanks for the positive home-town encouragement. Means a lot!

The straight-forward question you posed in your example of a car theft trial would raise no eyebrows at all. Yet in a sexual assault trial the consequences are plain to see.

The message being hammered into judges is clear: whether you think the female sexual assault complainant is credible or not, you must question her with kid gloves.

Comment: I forgot for the moment that primary and secondary Catholic schools in the States are private schools. In most of Canada Catholic schools are publicly funded... in Anglophone Canada we speak of "public" and "separate" (=Catholic) schools. Our problem is that this formerly just situation in which public schools were unambiguously protestant and separate schools were catholic, has been disrupted with the influx of Muslims and other non-Christian faiths who are busily setting up their own private, not-publicly funded schools. 

With the increase of secularism, the demand to defund Catholic schools will increase, despite constitutional protection. Our bishops are too fixated in their contentment with what we have to notice the injustice in favour of Catholics. They could use the existing constitutional protection to barter away Catholic privilege for a single public system in which all faiths (including secular) have the right to teach their religion as an optional subject. Not on radar.

Comment: The allegation we should be most careful with is that so-and-so lied.  Amazingly, some people don't know what it takes to prove a lie.  A lie is a false statement, KNOWN to be false by the person who utters it.  John Hobson, a Harvard man, should have learned that in 3rd grade.

Well, which is it?   Does she believe what she says (in which case she cannot possibly be a liar), or does she know the falsehood of what she says and says it anyway (in which case she IS a liar)?  

I mention these things as one who generally agrees with Pandora.  I don't believe she has ever lied, and have only rarely thought she is wrong.  Before one calls another a "liar," he at least ought to know what it means to lie, and it's hard to believe a Harvard man doesn't know.

Comment: I agree that epithets such as "conservative" and "progressive" can be inaccurate or reductive or misleading, but I don't agree that they're always useless. In the cases of e.g. Joseph Ratzinger and even more perhaps Henri de Lubac, we find an early, challenging pattern of innovation led to a ready acceptance of the way things have always been. We see that the Lubac-inspired "Lumen gentium" might have looked radical with its talk of the "people of God" and the dignity of the laity, but it's hardly a manifesto of revolution; and in fact it seems easily to have supported JPII's empowerment of the conservatives, including the hierarchalism and arch-sacerdotalism of Benedict XVI and even Raymond Burke (mein Gott!).

I was only suggesting something, but don't claim to know. For my part, I don't find Teilhard interesting, and see him through the eyes of disappointed biologists, e.g. Stephen Jay Gould, who accused Teilhard as being the nefarious evil genius behind the Piltdown Conspiracy.

Comment: First, faux-meats are kind of a misnomer: seitan and soy have been used for centuries as protein options for non meat-eaters in South and East Asia. Tofu is a food in itself. Seitan is a food in itself. They are used in dishes as substitutes for meat alternatives for centuries. There are faux-meat dishes in Asian restaurants that have just as long of a history as the meat-equivalent dishes themselves. To say that seitan has to be 100% like beef is ridiculous. 

Second, as many have pointed out, the point of a sloppy or diner food joint catering to vegans is because vegans don't SIMPLY PREFER BROCCOLI - they have cravings for oily, rich, and textured foods other than vegetables the same as meat eaters. The reason they eat non-meat things is for ETHICAL reasons. They refuse to continue to support killing living and pain-feeling beings for the sake of TASTE. 

Lastly, I think the reviewer came in with a mental block in mind. Hate for hipsters and "trendy" things leads this dinosaur review

Comment: I think in all fairness that before the Liberals end omnibus bills for good, they should have the opportunity to try one out for their political advantage. They have a lot of ground to make up after the disastrous Harper years, and Conservative complaints are falling on my deaf ears.

It is understandable that some Liberals may be miffed, but all things considered, a responsible government should not really make a concerted effort to get rid of a policy vehicle until they road-test it.

I do hope all the parties learn a lesson from this. If you don't want omnibus bills, don't present omnibus bills. If Trudeau did not present one here, the Conservatives would have no idea how horrible they are when you are in opposition. 

Clearly I like this government, and I'm willing to pardon their many apparent inconsistencies, up to a point. They are a long way from that, so I'll heave a contented sigh amidst the wailing and moaning from past champions of omnibus bills.

Your comment makes an assumption that is no longer true - that football supplies a mutal benefit to a given player, the other players, students and the community.

Football has become a very, very valuable brass ring at the hiigh schoool level.

Worth between $80,000 and $300,000.  The value of a 4 year ride at a University, including tuition, room and board.  

If you accept the value numbers as true, can you ask ANY family or kid to give up a chance at $80,000 - $300,000 in value in sacrifice for another kid?  Other students?  Or the community?  

What if they do, and then forfeit a legitimate shot at $80,000-$300,000?  Will those other interests or entities cover?

The problem is a system that makes it a $80,000-$300,000 proposition.

That's what has to change.  Until then, you really can't blame people (especially those ill-equipped or not trained to think differently) from reaching for the brass ring.

Comment: They fight it David because they are stuck in the 1960s. Our Legislative Majority has treated medical Marijuana like that since it was voted on and approved many years ago. No dispensaries, no way to even legally access seeds to start your own. They also made it near impossible to get an MM card, and if you did, you were subject to a courtesy check to make sure you were in compliance with the law, which is vague at best. Very few Doctors were willing to stick their neck out to give you a MM card. It is still that way today. They are treating recreational about the same. Comment: In the mid- to late 1930s France had the largest and most powerful army in the world, yet they failed to act against the fledgling German army when it violated the Versailles treaty and occupied the Rhineland. The French could have easily defeated the Germans, and removed Hitler from power, but they didn't - they sat back and watched as the Germans grew stronger, and before long, it was too late. 

Today, the US and its allies sit back and watch Kim develop nuclear-tipped ICBMs. And, they do nothing. Very, very soon, it will be too late.

Each experiment brings the North Koreans one step closer to their goal of building nuclear-tipped ICBMs that will reach North America. Once that happens,  it is a matter of when - not if - but when a nuclear missile from North Korea flattens a city in Japan, South Korea, the US or Canada. Make no mistake, it will absolutely, certainly happen. 

Those who do not learn from history are doomed to repeat it. We, evidently, have not learned a damn thing.

Comment: Yes, I assume it is. The Royal Commission‚Äôs role is to identify factors in institutions that contributed to the sexual abuse of children. It found that easy forgiveness in confession encouraged recidivism. The Commission recognized that the Catholic Church is not the only religion that has this problem, but the evidence mainly came from Catholic case studies and those who treated such priests. A civil reporting law and a canonical prohibition of absolution can work together to discourage this use (or abuse) of the sacrament.  A civil reporting law is useless if the confessor doesn‚Äôt know who the penitent is. A canonical prohibition, if widely publicized, will be much more effective because the abuser will know that it is pointless going to confession if he knows that absolution will be refused until he hands himself in. That‚Äôs why a change in canon law is so important.

Comment: An interesting quote from the piece: "What‚Äôs interesting here, noted a Royal Bank economist, is how the pace of mortgage borrowing is easing but Canadians are jumping into other forms of credit."

Multiple models could be proposed for why that is happening. Here is one far-out, zany, ridiculous model that could lead to that situation:

Step 1. The Vancouver and Toronto regions grow to include close to 30 percent of Canada's homes.
Step 2. The prices of those homes skyrocket to well over one million dollars from overseas money.
Step 3. Local workers there give up trying to get mortgages for dozens of times their annual salary.
Step 4. A massive drop in mortgage debt occurs because overseas money buys houses all cash down.
Step 5. Local workers, now relegated to renting, compete for expensive and rare available units.
Step 6. The high rents and very long commutes and lousy wages necessitate borrowing from banks.

Or wait a minute, is that model really far-out, zany and ridiculous?

Comment: Ah, but he's talking about the cities, not the burbs.  We grew up in the city in a complex built specifically for Veterans of WWII.   They were low rise apartments, 4 or 6 families in each building, with large fenced backyards spanning several at a time on either side of the laneway.   There was a similar complex built in the West end of the city, but I don't think they had the fenced yards we had.    There were enough kids in the complex to have teams to play hockey or volleyball or whatever game we wanted to play.

When I was small, an older kid carefully built a rink at one end of a yard so he and his friends could play hockey at night.   Not only were the younger kids able to skate during the day, but he also helped us build an ice slide beside it, complete with steps!  And there were no bullies in our neighbourhood - because they weren't tolerated.   These were not highrises.  The population was small enough that everybody knew each other.  Which wasn't always a good thing.  HA!

Comment: No one knows how to gauge te outcome based on the ranked ballot.  But isn't the challenge greater than that?   
Each EDA counts as 100 points and the first candidate to get 16901 points, or more, is the winner.  This means that EDA's with a small number of members carry a lot of weight.  If one candidate has 28% support concentrated in many EDA's with few members, that candidate ha a much better chance than another candidate with 35% support concentrated in a few ridings in the GTA.
This is the same approach the Liberals used to choose Justin Trudeau.  Apparently, he had broad support getting over 80% of the points on the first round.  This time around, it seems like a real crap shoot.

In the autumn of 1971 I was standing on a dock in northern Manitoba ... a newly-minted school-teacher attending an orientation session before heading still further north. A young native guy walks out along the dock and joins me at the end. A beautiful evening. Silence. Maybe geese overhead ... 

He speaks ... not to me ... but out ... clearly ... onto the big calm lake.

"There is an old legend from my people. <pause> If a hunter makes a very strong bow ... and goes out onto the land and shoots an arrow straight up into the sky ... <pause again> it will strike a large airplane. And on that airplane there will be at least one Indian going to a conference."

Comment: PERA's antiquated investment strategy has not helped returns. Index funds have beaten the old pension asset allocation models for many years. College endowments and more enlightened state pension funds are switching large chunks of assets to passive investments.  The projected 7.25% return, weighed down as it will be by large investments in fixed income investments, is wildly unrealistic. There is no reason to keep more than two or three years of pension obligations invested in fixed income assets. There is also zero justification to invest in foreign stocks. That diversification argument was destroyed years ago. If the US stock market catches a cold, the rest of the world will be coming down with double pneumonia.  This ain't rocket science.

It was surprising not to see coverage of PERA's multi-million dollar slush fund for small business. This is PERA's lame attempt to pick winners and losers, something governments have never been particularly successful at doing.

Comment: Well then Phil, you must be opposed to the Supreme Court interpreting the First Amendment to mean that corporations possess a separate freedom of speech, and that money is speech. Right? Our Constitution isn't a roadmap or an operators manual giving specific instructions about how to do everything. Nobody in 1788 had any idea, for instance, that we would need regulation of radio spectra. Our Constitution sets broad goals and divides powers among the federal government and the states, and defines broadly the establishment of an Executive, a Legislative body, and a Judicial hierarchy. If our Constitution didn't need daily interpretation we would have no need for the Judicial. Without the Judicial the Executive would usurp all powers, and we don't want that, do we. Right now we are seeing that check and balance impeding the raw will of our president. It's a great show and we need to pay less attention to Trump's absurd theatrics and keep our eyes on the real show.

Comment: People must decide what they want from the government. Do you want excellent, skilled employees that are dedicated to public service on the other end of the phone or do you want someone who can perform the basic job requirements at an average level? If you want to pay less, understand there will be average employees and average results. There will be a good chance you encounter poor service or an error in your service throughout the year. 

The state basically trained me to get a better job in the private sector. My workload increased by over 50% in a few years, I had no room for advancement, and I saved the state about quadruple my salary through identifying an unconsidered (and still not publicly discussed problem), but had no way of being rewarded beyond my 3%. But what finally made me quit was the anger of citizens, who had never dealt with me or my office before but had such hate for the government that they would start the conversation by telling me how stupid and useless I was.

Comment: Working as a processor is hard work, 26 years ago I was pull off a ship in Dutch harbor and flown to anchorage. A meeting with Senator Ted Steven's and Harvey Samuelson sr. - we talked about jobs opportunities for people living in western Alaska communities also the trash and debris from at sea bottom trawlers. This meeting during the North Pacific fishery management council would open up a lot of opportunities for western Alaska communities. Contracts back then were 120 days and 16 hrs a day. Sleeping conditions and the food had no complaints. During my 13 complete contacts I seen up to one third of the workers leave when we off load at Dutch harbor or Kodiak .I almost quit a few times - Harvey encouraged me to keep working, , the CDQ program did not come on a silver platter and was thought up when I was sorting pollack , look at all the opportunities the $$ the CDQ program has to offer. Ideas on how to invest in higher pay for CDQ residents also do value-added to keep the jobs here.

Comment: Who gives a crap where the word originated. I spoke about definition, not etymology. 

It's utterly irrelevant where it originated or what it meant when it was created. What matters is what it means today, what people understand when they hear it. Not what it meant once upon a time.

The word "proves"used to mean "to test and show to be false", giving English the expression "the exception that proves the rule" - which literally meant "the exception that shows the rule isn't actually a rule and is not really true".

Over time "proves" lost the meaning of "to show the falsehood of" and only the meaning of "to show it's true" remained, and the proverb survives even though it's modern day meaning makes no sense. It's a kind of bizarre claim that the the rule is true BECAUSE there are exceptions to it.

Words change their meanings over time - and if you don't know the current meaning, you cannot communicate honestly, logically or usefully.

Comment: It's not necessary to point out that Cal Thomas is himself about as rigid as they get, suffering as he does from ideological rigor mortis.  

But he make this misleading statement: "Many on the left believe school choice should not be available to poor children, not because school choice is a bad idea but because the Democratic Party doesn't want to alienate teachers' unions that oppose it."  

The issue here is the survival of public education as it has existed for over a century.  "School choice," in practice means a free-for-all sort-out according to income and, for the poor, place of residence.  More enabled chldren quickly gravitate to better performing schools, leaving the public schools, who have no choice about the students they will accept (as charter schools do), to take the social and academic problem kids.  Better teachers naturally gravitate to a better class of student, so the public schools also end up with the worst teachers.  In short, dump those who need help most.

Comment: This article is a shining example of raw ignorance in how the system works.  Joan admits she's biased, but attempts to minimize it by misdirecting the reader as to the reasons for her bias.  Fact: the 60-vote threshold only becomes relevant if the minority party stages a filibuster. Breaking a filibuster, or ‚Äúmoving for cloture‚Äù in the parlance of the Senate, requires 60 votes. A vote to approve requires only 51.  Neither of Obama‚Äôs appointees faced a filibuster. Nor did President Bush‚Äôs first nominee, John Roberts.  Seven of the eight justices currently on the Court, prior to Gorsuch, did not face cloture votes, meaning they were not subject to the 60-vote threshold to which Democrats are insisting nominees are consistently held. 
The only nominees to face filibusters along ideological lines were filibustered by Democrats. Gorsuch wasn't going to be filibustered for any other reason than that he was Trump's nominee.
What's weakening our Democracy is fanatical progressivism.

Comment: It certainly wouldn't be difficult for healthcare providers to establish a set price for procedures that took contingency circumstances into account.  The Oklahoma Surgery Center does just that to account for potential emergencies that might take place during operations, for example, and there are certain cash-only doctors who list their prices.  
As you point out, there is a parasitic relationship between providers and insurance companies, but honestly this is an issue that could easily be solved with existing anti-monopoly legislation.  The contention that a whole new law like the ACA and a wide-ranging bureaucracy to implement it was needed was fallacious from the beginning, and the GOP's proposed law just keeps the charade alive.

Comment: I have read two book on the FAIR TAX. There are a few more. There are many issues with the concept. Least of which is it will reguire no IRS or other agency to audit or verify what is collected.  Let alone verify who is getting the rebates. The Fair Tax book use the idea there would be no reason for cheating on your reporting.  Really no cheating or other deception by anyone.  We can just trust everyone to be 100% truthful. 

The big dollars from income taxes come from corporations and they will continue to have lots of questionable deductions that the Fair tax books seem to ignore.  The basic concept of the Fair Tax is simple for those who only have income from wages. When you toss in investments and owner operated business the fog appears to surround what is going to be considered taxable income.   

Plus the FAIR TAX does not deal with taxes such as excise taxes, import duties, and an assortment of other taxes. Most of which affect business more than individuals.

Comment: A party of five tourists from Nome, accompanied by an old-timer chef, travel by snowmachines to Fairbanks. During the first day goings-on, the tourist are rude and obnoxious. That evening, the chef includes a handful of moose nuggets to the stew. He asks the tourists, "How's the stew?" Their answer, "Tastes like moose shit!" Just then the chef pulls out a revolver and says, "The next complaint will be met with lead." Along the trail the following day, no rude behavior and all is quiet. That night the chef adds more nuggets to the stew. No complaints. Third night, the chef adds more nuggets. Still, no complaints. Fourth night, just outside Fairbanks, the chef asks, "How's the stew?" The tourists reply, "Tastes like moose shit...but good!"

Comment: If Trump is set on shutting us out, we need China.  Period. Let individuals and companies do business with individuals and companies in China, I say.  Besides, China's human rights situation is often misrepresented.  They do oppress political opposition, which is repugnant.  But their people are free to engage in capitalism, and the people are also free to travel for business and pleasure around the globe.  This isn't the China of Mao, not even awful like Castro's Cuba.  And we are not going to change China anytime soon.  Trade with them.

Comment: "....The fact that we have a crisis of thousands of murdered and missing indigenous women and girls in a country like Canada suggests that state-based racism, violence and neglect continue today..."
.
.
.
Actually, I believe the number is just over 1,000 in total since the mid 1970's, and it pretty much matches the general levels of missing/murdered to society as a whole over the entire period.

This came from a G&M article within the last year. The solve rate at 90% is almost identical, as is the 80%+ rate of the victim knowing/being related to the perp factor.

It only seems like a crisis because :

1. When you have relatively "small" numbers, (1,000 / 40 years + 25 per year) they are likely to come in "clumps", and thus look large

2. They also tend to be large for a given community. If there are 2 from a band of 300 in a single year, it has "oversize" implications...

Note: this is not to diminish any of these cases, or demean the loss to either the families, or community.

Comment: ... and that's where you run into trouble, not because you're opposed to Islamic extremists, but because in order to oppose one flavour of crazy you find yourself in bed with a different flavour.

Do I oppose violent extremists?  Yep.  ALL of them... but if I were to target one group, I'd find myself aligned with a different group because there's plenty of crazy to go around.

Immigrants and Refugees already face a rigorous vetting process, and the few terrorists acts that have been committed on Canadian soil have not for the most part been committed by immigrants or refugees.  If I thought there'd be an EFFECTIVE way to keep Crazy out of my country, I'd be all for it... but that wouldn't change the Crazy we already have.

Crazy is going to be crazy.  I can't fix that.  What I can do is vote for policies that help people get and keep work, make a decent wage and make sure that if they DO go bonkers, they stay in prison for a very very long time.

Comment: Fans have no desire for "brakes", nor should they, they are fans after all. Just a few months ago, fans were proclaiming  (some still are) "journeyman", "backup at best", "average ceiling - maybe", "Trevor Orton" and many more less complimentary names and insults. Through all that, a few of us were defending TS, saying "it's too early for those labels" and very few were saying "pump the brakes" then.

So, now that there's more data and the bandwagon is getting dangerously top heavy, nobody really cares (or wants) a safe ride with brakes pumped at every turn, especially when you'er 2-0 on the first 2 turns. Fans want the thrill of being 1st to cross the finish line, with every heart stopping moment and every breath taking spectacle that makes them cling to their seats and squeal for more along the way. That's football, that's entertainment and that's what fans love.

So damn the brakes, full speed ahead! GO BRONCOS!
